ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: In our sustained engagement with the life and works of Charles Baudelaire, I honed my close-reading and analytical skills, gained insights into 19th-century France, and learned a lot about French poetic conventions (meter, rhyme, scansion).
I developed a survey understanding of Baudelaire's works and their contemporary applications
I certainly gained a greater understanding of Baudelaire's work and biography, and a better understanding of French poetry in the 19th century generally.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: Strengths: The works read and secondary resources studied were all incredibly interesting and enlightening. Class discussions were always very enriching. Weaknesses: N/A

The seminar is completely unstructured, making it difficult to approach. There are no overarching themes given to look out for in the readings, and the guidelines for important assignments are only disseminated verbally. There are no rubrics. The presentation component was very interesting and allowed each student to bring some of their own knowledge into a course which generally only allows room for formal poetic analysis.
I'd say the course was strong overall.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: I would certainly recommend this class to any student who is interested in 19th-century French poetry. Our sustained engagement with the works of Baudelaire was incredibly enriching, and Prof. Connolly is an incredible professor!
I'd recommend it if you're curious about Baudelaire and will never have another opportunity to examine his works in a group setting. Otherwise, there are much better courses in the department.

Yes, but be aware that, as one might expect of a course covering most of a writer's oeuvre, there will be a considerable amount of reading that may or may not feel managable week to week depending on your other commitments.
